title.narrative: Improving Incomes and Livelihoods for Rice Farmers in Jowhar through Investment

description.narrative: Local rice farmers in Jowhar District have a limited production capacity. This has affected the rice supply of Danwadaag company. The produced rice has been mixed with small and long grans, affecting the quality of the processed rice and, as a result, the market price. Rice farmers have limited farm management capacity, and their numbers must be increased in order for the company to receive an adequate supply of rice and increase its income. Rice farmers' income is also very low due to their poor farming capacity, and this project is critical in order to improve farmers' income as well as. There is high market demand of local rice and Danwadaag has no capacity to meet the market demand

title.narrative: Kaashif Youth Livelihoods Project in Mogadishu and Jowhar

description.narrative: Sector: Youth skills training and job placement. Beneficiaries: 200 youth, of whom 100 are women. Summary: This project will provide marketable skills training for 200 youth in Mogadishu (Dharkenley, Hodan and Waberi districts) and Middle Shabelle (Jowhar district) over two years. Beneficiaries will be trained in: secretarial and computer skills; electricity; mobile phone repair; carpentry, auto-mechanics; beauty and hairdressing. Trainees will also engage in business and job placements to acquire experience and get employed to improve their livelihoods.

description.narrative: Somali Consultant Association (SOCA) is USADF's local partner for the portfolio in Somalia. They assist grantees with implementation issues, as well as carrying out due diligence, monitoring and evaluation, and more.

title.narrative: USADF Somali Grantee Workshop Cooperative Agreement Grant

description.narrative: USADF will host its annual Somali grantee workshop from February 12-16, 2017 in Djibouti City, Djibouti. This workshop will enable Somalia NGOs implementing youth training and employment programs to meet and learn best practices for implementing these type of activities across Somalia. The $55,521 grant will allow SOCA to make purchases for the conference on behalf of the 26 Somali grantee attendees. Purchases under the grant include lodging, airfare, taxis, visas, and M&IE.

mailing-address.narrative: 1400 I St. NW Suite 1000, Washington, DC 20005

title.narrative: Improving Livelihoods in Fishing Communities in Berbera, Hiis and Maydh

description.narrative: Yovenco will train 100 males in modern fishing techniques in order to increase productivity. This group will be trained in the use of fishing nets, solar lanterns, safety glasses, long lines, echo sound, and GPs packs. The fishers will be able to catch more fish after this training. Yovenco also prepared a market for their product, promising that SOMTONA Factory would take all of their fish.

title.narrative: Kaamil Microfinance

description.narrative: Sector: Microfinance, Beneficiaries: At-risk youth, Summary: Kaamil Microfinance Institution will provide micro-loans to 250 Somali youth who have graduated from previous USADF job-training projects, with the goal of aiding them to establish small businesses or expand their current businesses.

description.narrative: This grant will provide support to SOCA, USADF's in-country partner in Somalia. Funds will be used for staff salaries, office space, administrative support, program monitoring, a program audit, and capacity building.

description.narrative: ClearSky will install a technology platform consisting of solar PV, solar batteries,and hybrid all-in-one inverters that can operate in both on and off-grid mode for 12 SMEs and households in Somaliland and Puntland.

title.narrative: SOCWE Alternative Youth Skills Training and Employment Project

description.narrative: Sector: Youth skills training and job placement. Beneficiaries: 200 youth, of whom 110 are women. Summary: This project will provide marketable skills training for 200 youth in Mogadishu over two years. Beneficiaries will be trained in: journalism, secretarial skills, welding, electricity, and tailoring and tie-dye clothing production. SOCWE aims to help 75% of the trained youth secure employment, while the other 25% will be supported in starting their own businesses.

mailing-address.narrative: 1400 I St. NW Suite 1000, Washington, DC 20005
